edge_notes.LVFAILURE -> LVEDVOLUME: Strong physiological basis; left ventricular failure reduces ejection and increases end-diastolic volume.
edge_notes.LVEDVOLUME -> CVP: Increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume can raise central venous pressure through backward pressure.
edge_notes.LVEDVOLUME -> PCWP: Physiologically, elevated left ventricular end-diastolic volume increases pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.
edge_notes.LVFAILURE -> STROKEVOLUME: Left ventricular failure directly reduces stroke volume.
edge_notes.PULMEMBOLUS -> PAP: Pulmonary embolus increases pulmonary artery pressure.
edge_notes.INTUBATION -> SHUNT: Endotracheal intubation can lead to increased intrathoracic pressure and physiological shunt.
edge_notes.MINVOLSET -> VENTMACH: Mechanical ventilator settings determine ventilator mode.
edge_notes.KINKEDTUBE -> PRESS: A kinked ventilator tube can increase airway pressure.
edge_notes.INTUBATION -> VENTLUNG: Intubation enables mechanical ventilation of the lungs.
edge_notes.INTUBATION -> MINVOL: Intubation allows for controlled minute volume.
edge_notes.VENTALV -> PVSAT: Alveolar ventilation affects pulmonary vascular saturation.
edge_notes.PVSAT -> SAO2: Pulmonary vascular saturation affects arterial oxygen saturation.
edge_notes.VENTALV -> ARTCO2: Alveolar ventilation affects arterial CO2 levels.
edge_notes.ERRLOWOUTPUT -> HRBP: Low cardiac output alarms may influence heart rate and blood pressure alarms.
edge_notes.HR -> HRBP: Heart rate directly affects blood pressure dynamics.
edge_notes.ERRCAUTER -> HREKG: Electrocautery can interfere with EKG readings.
edge_notes.HR -> HREKG: Heart rate is a component of EKG interpretation.
edge_notes.ERRCAUTER -> HRSAT: Electrocautery can interfere with saturation readings.
edge_notes.STROKEVOLUME -> CO: Stroke volume is a key determinant of cardiac output.
edge_notes.TPR -> BP: Total peripheral resistance is a primary determinant of blood pressure.
edge_notes.CO -> BP: Cardiac output contributes to systemic blood pressure.
